citations.narrative:
During the afternoon inspection upon entering the off-exhibit area, the male burrowing owl was noted on the ground face
down in the sand outside of the burrow and not breathing. A new keeper had just left the area, and the morning check had
been performed but there were no notations or reports of any issues with burrowing owls. The attending veterinarian
determined that the owl most likely died overnight. The gross necropsy report indicated the owl had signs of renal disease
consistent with an older animal.
Although the new keeper received general training on recognizing anormal behaviors in animals. The new keeper was
inexperienced in noticing abnormal behaviors for burrowing owls.
Adequately trained employees or attendants must be utilized to maintain the professionally acceptable level of husbandry
and handling practices set forth in this subpart. Such practices must be conducted under the supervision of a bird
caretaker who has appropriate experience in the husbandry and care of birds that are being managed at the zoo.
Facilities must ensure all employees are adequately trained to work with avian species.
Correct by June 27, 2025
NOTE: The facility started an investigation into the matter on the day of inspection.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by August 10, 2025 - 60 days from 1st RL Inspection or the
applicant will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your
next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires on July , 2025.
n

narrative:
3.159 
   
Employees 
During the afternoon inspection upon entering the off-exhibit area, the male burrowing owl was noted on the ground face 
down in the sand outside of the burrow and not breathing. A new keeper had just left the area, and the morning check had 
been performed but there were no notations or reports of any issues with burrowing owls. The attending veterinarian 
determined that the owl most likely died overnight. The gross necropsy report indicated the owl had signs of renal disease 
consistent with an older animal.  
 
Although the new keeper received general training on recognizing anormal behaviors in animals. The new keeper was 
inexperienced in noticing abnormal behaviors for burrowing owls.  
 
Adequately trained employees or attendants must be utilized to maintain the professionally acceptable level of husbandry 
and handling practices set forth in this subpart. Such practices must be conducted under the supervision of a bird 
caretaker who has appropriate experience in the husbandry and care of birds that are being managed at the zoo. 
Facilities must ensure all employees are adequately trained to work with avian species.  
Correct by June 27, 2025 
 
NOTE: The facility started an investigation into the matter on the day of inspection. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by August 10, 2025 - 60 days from 1st RL Inspection or the 
applicant will forfeit the license fee and must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your 
next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires on July , 2025.
